head.title: Press in Moscow Is Choosing Sides

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Government, Philanthropy and NGO

hedline.hl1: Press in Moscow Is Choosing Sides

block.p: "Hang in there, Boris Nikolayevich," a television announcer, Svetlana Sorokina, said encouragingly in the middle of the Channel 2 nightly news, one of the more obvious statements of support for the President broadcast today.

At an emergency session of Parliament today, legislators accused the press of taking a "pro-presidential position." After months of pleading for more objective reporting, some legislators have urged that parliament control television stations.

"Hang in there, Boris Nikolayevich," a television announcer, Svetlana Sorokina, said encouragingly in the middle of the Channel 2 nightly news, one of the more obvious statements of support for the President broadcast today.

At an emergency session of Parliament today, legislators accused the press of taking a "pro-presidential position." After months of pleading for more objective reporting, some legislators have urged that parliament control television stations.

Although a great deal of commentary supported President Boris N. Yeltsin, his opponents have had their chance. Hours after the President instituted "special rule" on Saturday night, the Vice President, the head of the Constitutional Court and the deputy chairman of Parliament were on the air in protest.
And Den, a hard-line nationalist newspaper, came out today with an article condemning the "former" President.
